results.title: Child at the centre
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australian mosaic”.
In this frank and uninhibited documentary parents and childcare workers talk candidly about that widely used but rarely understood term - multiculturalism. Rather than separate and draw attention to differences, the childcare experts interviewed here create an environment where cultures fuse and blend. “The Child at the Centre” shows us a rich slice of Australia, very much a ‘hands on’ approach to early childhood education that benefits all children whatever their cultural background.

Episode of Series “Australian mosaic”.
Describes problems of disabled non-English speaking immigrants in Australia. Shows how some of these special groups have received assistance through the help of ADEC (Action on Disability within Ethnic Communities).

results.title: The Story of a thing = La Storia di una cosa
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australian mosaic”.
A theatrical interpretation by a community theatre group, of the experiences of Italian women migrants, and those of their daughters. Combines stage sequences and interviews to present an appeal to listen, with humour and pathos, from a section of the community which is rarely heard. Italian dialogue, English subtitles.

results.title: Try your fortune
results.creator_credit: Ziyin Wang, Barbara Mariotti and SBS-TV
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australian mosaic”.
Looks at immigration and cross cultural marriages. This program focuses on Chinese immigrants and marriages between Chinese citizens and Australians. Two Australian/Chinese couples are interviewed on aspects such as why they decided to get married, how their families felt about the marriage and how each Chinese person coped with language and monetary barriers when they first arrived in Australia. The program also looks at overseas students and why they are attracted to making Australia their permanent home. Discusses the steps Chinese spouses must take to convince the immigration department that the marriage is a ‘real’ one, and not one of convenience. Some interviews are conducted in Chinese. No subtitles are provided.

Two Australian/Chinese couples are interviewed on aspects such as why they decided to get married, how their families felt about the marriage and how each Chinese person coped with language and monetary barriers when they first arrived in Australia. The program also looks at overseas students and why they are attracted to making Australia their permanent home. Discusses the steps Chinese spouses must take to convince the immigration department that the marriage is a ‘real’ one, and not one of convenience. Some interviews are conducted in Chinese. No subtitles are provided.

results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australian mosaic”.
Shows the life and work of officers and crew aboard the ship, Cape Moreton, as they maintain shipping beacons and lighthouses in the tropics around Torres Strait. Examines the role of the Australian Lighthouse Service.

results.title: Not for hire
results.creator_credit: David Caesar, Georgia Allen and Australia. Special Broadcasting Service
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australian mosaic”.
Taxi driving is a competitive business but you can’t beat it for a sense of freedom, say the drivers. However, not all the drivers are in the game out of freedom of choice. Many are overseas immigrants whose professional qualifications proved unacceptable in Australia - they had to make a living somehow.

results.title: A meeting of ways
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australian mosaic”.
Describes the process of organising a community art project for a newly-opened community centre in Melbourne called Ross House. This program records the joys, the frustrations, the tears, the highs and the lows in the making of community art.

results.title: What do you really do for a job? = [May Day]
results.creator_credit: Sally Ingleton, Philip Howe and Australia. Special Broadcasting Service
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australian mosaic”.
The first of May is International Labour Day marking the struggle to achieve the eight hour working day. The Northern Territory is one of the few States still celebrating May 1st as a holiday. This program follows the preparations by community groups, trade unions and artistic directors, Neil Cameron and Jan McDonald, to revitalise the 1989 May Day celebrations in Darwin by creating a lively and colourful parade and festival where workers could have a good time and still prove unity is strength.
